title: 103_s2476
content: The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction. Spousal IRA contribution rules amended to allow deduction based on combined compensation of both spouses. The limitation is the lesser of $2,000 or the sum of individual's and spouse's compensations minus spouse's deduction. Applies to any individual meeting specified criteria. The amendment allows a deduction for spousal IRA contributions based on combined compensation of both spouses. The amendment applies to individuals filing a joint return where one spouse has less compensation than the other. Amendments also include changes to specific sections and an effective date of taxable years beginning after December 31, 1994. Distributions from certain plans can be used penalty-free to buy first homes, pay for higher education or long-term care, or by the long-term unemployed. Distributions from certain retirement plans can be used penalty-free for first home purchases, educational expenses, or long-term care. The new paragraphs define qualified first-time homebuyer distributions as payments used for qualified acquisition costs for a first-time homebuyer's principal residence within 60 days. The new paragraphs define qualified first-time homebuyer distributions as payments for acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence, including settlement and closing costs. A first-time homebuyer is defined as an individual who had no ownership interest in a principal residence in the 3-year period before acquiring the residence. The new paragraphs define qualified first-time homebuyer distributions as payments for acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence, including settlement and closing costs. A first-time homebuyer is an individual who had no ownership interest in a principal residence during the 3-year period before acquiring the residence. The term "principal residence" has the same meaning as in section 1034, and the term "date of acquisition" refers to the date of a binding contract. The term "date of acquisition" in section 1034 refers to the date when a binding contract is entered into or construction of a principal residence begins. If a distribution fails to meet requirements due to a delay in acquiring the residence, the amount may be contributed to an individual retirement plan within 120 days. The term "qualified higher education expenses" includes tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment required for the enrollment or attendance of the taxpayer, spouse, child, or grandchild. The taxpayer, spouse, child, or grandchild can have qualified higher education expenses at an eligible educational institution. The amount of expenses is reduced by any excludable income. Qualified long-term care expenses include payments for services and insurance. Qualified long-term care services refer to necessary diagnostic, preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitative, and maintenance services for functionally impaired individuals, aimed at providing assistance with daily living activities they are unable to perform. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a functionally impaired individual who requires assistance with daily living activities as certified by a licensed healthcare practitioner. This assistance must be provided according to a prescribed plan of care. The curr_chunk explains the criteria for an individual to be considered functionally impaired and in need of assistance with daily living activities. This assistance must be provided as outlined in a prescribed plan of care. The curr_chunk outlines activities of daily living and defines a licensed health care practitioner as a physician or registered nurse. The curr_chunk defines a licensed health care practitioner as a physician, registered nurse, or qualified community care case manager, as determined by the Secretary after consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. A case manager is an individual or entity with experience in providing case management services, assessing functional and cognitive impairment, not a relative of the individual receiving services, and meeting requirements set by the Secretary. The text discusses penalty-free distributions for unemployed individuals from individual retirement plans under certain conditions, including receiving unemployment compensation for 12 consecutive weeks. The text discusses amendments to Section 401(k) and Section 403(b) regarding penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses. Amendments to Section 403(b)(11) allow penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses. Effective after the enactment of this Act.
